scrolling, and whenever the cursor passes beyond the bottom of the window it will reappear from the top. SCROLL
ON starts the scrolling process again, so that a new line is inserted when the cursor tries to pass beyond the bottom

example demonstrating these commands to be found under the SET CURS command, which is below.

descriptions.text: Define the shape of the text cursor

content.text: To customise the text cursor into something a little more personalised, you can change its shape into anything you
like, providing you limit yourself to the eight lines of eight bits each that represent its appearance. Lines are
numbered one to eight from top to bottom, and every bit set to 1 results in a pixel drawn in the current cursor pen
colour, whereas a zero displays the current paper colour. To familiarise yourself with the technique, try the next
example, which changes the text cursor into a Hallowe'en mask:
Set Curs L1 L2 , L3 L4 L5, L6 , L7, L8
Your routine will appear slightly different from that, because the system automatically strips away any leading zeros

ink paper, outline and pattern to be used by the slider control box. If negative values are used for either pattern, a
sprite image will be commandeered from the sprite bank, allowing even more spectacular effects. Try this example:

slider bars needs to be included in your main program. As always, remember to test out the ready-made example

descriptions.text: Instructions and functions to manage the timer and time in AOZ
Reserved variable. Return / Set the number of millisecond since the application was launched. Work in 1/50th of seconds in Amiga emulation

content.text: The TIMER reserved variable containing the number of seconds since it was reset. It is a floating point number on modern machines and the precision will reach 0.001
On old machine, TIMER is an integer number increase by 1 every 1/50th of seconds
This example will make things clear...
Print "Please press a key when you want"...
Print Timer			// If you wait for exactly one second, it will print "1"
Print "Please press a key when you want"...
Print Timer			// If you wait for exactly one second, it will print "50"
You can use Timer as a seed for the randomize instruction, providing that you do not set the value of the time when you application starts.
The best place to use this technique is immediately after the user has entered some data into the computer. Even a
simple key-press to start a game will work perfectly, and generate truly random numbers.

descriptions.text: Pauses the application until the next screen refresh

content.text: This instruction is fundamental to stabilize the speed of your application and syncheronize it perfectly with the display rate: it forces AOZ to "give back the hand" to the system, and wait for the next refresh of the display.

Not only this "giving back the hand to the system" is a mandatory thing to do to ensure that the computer where your application is running does not freeze, it also ensures the speed of your application
The rule is: *ALWAYS* use a Wait Vbl instruction in long loops, or in the main loop of your applicaiton.
This example display the refresh rate of your monitor, usually 60...
Print "Press a key when you are ready!"
Wait Vbl 		// Synchronize the number of loops to the speed of the display
Print "Your monitor refresh rate is: "; Count / Timer

descriptions.text: Pauses the application during a certain period of time

content.text: The WAIT command tells the computer to stop the program and wait for as long as you want before moving on to
the next instruction. The number that follows it is the waiting time, specified as a floating point number in seconds.
The following example forces the program to wait for two seconds and 10 milliseconds:
The following example that works in Amiga emulation forces the program to wait for two seconds:

parameters.name: time
parameters.text: Duration of the pause, expressed in milliseconds. (Ticks in Amiga emulation)

Swap the content of two variables

content.text: Use the SWAP command to swap over the data between any two variables of the same type. For example:

parameters.text: First variable

parameters.text: Second variable

descriptions.text: Used in a procedure, make the variable visible by the procedure above

content.text: There is an alternative method of passing data between a procedure and the main program. When SHARED is
placed inside a procedure definition, it takes a list of local variables separated by commas and transforms them into
global variables, which can be directly accessed from the main program. Of course, if you declare any arrays as
global using this technique, they must already have been dimensioned in the main program.
EXAMPLE can now read and write information to the global variables A and B. If you need to share an array, it
In a very large program, it is often convenient for different procedures to share the same set of global variables. This
offers an easy way of transferring large amounts of information between your procedures.

parameters.name: variable
parameters.text: Variable to share

descriptions.text: Make a variable visible in the entire application

content.text: GLOBAL sets up a list of variables that can be accessed from absolutely anywhere in your program. This is a
simplified single command, designed to be used without the need for an explicit SHARED statement in your
procedure definitions. Here is an example:
As with disc names, the "wild card" characters * and ? can also be included. In this case, the * character is
used to mean "match this with any list of characters in the variable name, until the next control character is
reached", and the ? character means "match this with any single character in the variable name". So the next line
would define every variable as global:
Now look at the following example:
That line would declare the following variables as shared:
- Any variable beginning with the character V, followed by any other characters, or on its own.
- Any variable beginning with the letters VAR, followed by any other characters, and ending with the characters END.
Any variable beginning with A, followed by any single letter, followed by OS, followed by any other characters.
GLOBAL or SHARED should be employed before the first use of the variable, otherwise it will have no effect on
an interpreted program, although it will affect programs compiled with the AOZ transpiler.
Only strings may be used for this technique. Global and shared arrays cannot be defined using wild cards. These
must be defined individually, using brackets. Also, if you try to use an expression in this way, an error will be
In that case, the A$ variable would be regarded as global, and it would not be taken as a wild card for subsequent
With AOZ, you are able to define global arrays from a procedure, even if the array is not created at root level, as follows:

parameters.name: variable
parameters.text: Variable to share

descriptions.text: Return the "memory address" of a variable, a reference number allowing you direct access to the variable

content.text: Making this kind of instruction was simple in the old days as variables were real chunks of memory that you could access directly. It is not the case anymore with modern language.

In order to implement the Varptr instruction, that many users of AMOS would say was very useful, we have to cheat: the value returned by Varptr is not a real address, but a magic number that will "act" as an address in intsructions such as "poke" and "peek".
It also allows interesting features, like getting inside of your application the *name* of the variable referenced by the address, it's type etc.
Basically everything you need to make a debugger, directly in AOZ!
This _will_ work in a future version:
The Poke and Peek series of instruction detect this magic number and simulate the action int he variable...

parameters.name: variable
parameters.text: Variable to get the "address" from

return.text: A magic number referencing the variable

descriptions.text: Define a new array, or a list of arrays. The number of dimension is not limited, yet only by the memory imprint and the machine the application is running on, be careful with large arrays!

content.text: The DIM command is used to dimension an array, and the variables in your record collection table could be set up with a first line like this:
Each dimension in the table is held inside round brackets, and if there is more than one element in a dimension each
number must be separated from the next by a comma.
Element numbers in arrays always start from zero, so your first and last entries might contain these variables:
To extract elements from your array, you could then add something like this to your example program:
These tables can have as many dimensions as you like, and each dimension can have up to 65,0(K) elements. Here are some more modest examples:

parameters.name: dimension1
parameters.text: First dimension

parameters.name: dimension2
parameters.text: Second dimension

parameters.name: dimensionX
parameters.text: Any number of dimensions, only limited by memory.

descriptions.text: Sort all elements in an array

content.text: The SORT instruction arranges the contents of any array into ascending order, and the array may contain integers, floating point numbers or strings.
The starting point of your table is specified by the a$(0) parameter, and it must always be set to the first item in the array, which is item number zero. For example:
Print "to stop entry and begin sort"

parameters.name: array
parameters.text: The array to sort

descriptions.text: Search an array for a value

content.text: MATCH searches through an array that has already gone through the SORT process, looking for a given value. If
the value is found then x is loaded with the relevant index number. However, if the search is not successful the result
will be negative. If you take the absolute value of this result, the item which came closest to your original search
parameter is provided. Only arrays with a single dimension can be checked in this way, and they must already be
sorted before MATCH can be called.
For X=0 To N-1 : Read D$(X) : Next X
For X=1 To N: Print D$(X) : Next X: Goto REINPUT
Print "Not found. Nearest to ";D$(1) : Goto JMP
Print "Not found. Nearest to ";D$(N) : Goto JMP
If POS>0 Then Print "Found ",DS(POS);" in record ";POS
If POS<0 Then Inc POS : Print "Not found. Nearest to ":DS(Abs(POS))
Test that example out by entering various inputs, including the names of planets, single characters in upper and
lower case and "print all data". Obviously MATCH can be used with the INSTR function to set up a powerful parser
routine, for interpreting user input in an adventure game.

parameters.name: array
parameters.text: The array to search

parameters.name: value
parameters.text: The value to find. Must be of the same type (number or string) than the array

return.text: The index of the item if found, -1 if not found

descriptions.text: Constant: boolean value TRUE

content.text: On modern machines, in all the conditional operations such as IF ... THEN and REPEAT ... UNTIL, the value of 1 is used to represent
TRUE, and the value of 0 is used to represent FALSE.
In Amiga and Atari emulation, the value of True is 1.

return.text: True

descriptions.text: Constant: boolean value FALSE

content.text: On modern machines, in all the conditional operations such as IF ... THEN and REPEAT ... UNTIL, the value of 1 is used to represent
TRUE, and the value of 0 is used to represent FALSE.
In Amiga and Atari emulation, the value of True is 1.

return.text: FALSE

descriptions.text: Test if a variable has been defined. Only valid if automatic definition of variable is switched off when transpiling (TODO! link to tag)

content.text: As in Javascript, AOZ allow you to detect if a variable has been defined.
This function will only work if you use the tag "autoVariables" TODO.
Print Is Defined( A$ )			// Will print "False"
Print A$						// Will generate an error
Print Is Defined( A$ )			// Will print "True"
Print A$						// Will not generate an error as A$ was automatically defined as "" by the AOZ transpiler.

return.text: TRUE if the variable is defined, FALSE if not

content.text: The ADD command can be used in two way:
The ADD command can be used to add the result of an expression to a whole number variable. immediately. It is the
There is a more complex version of ADD, which is ideal for handling certain loops much more quickly than the
equivalent separate instructions. When Base number and Top number parameters are included, ADD is the
Until V=11 : Rem This loop is infinite as V is always <11~~~
The ADD instruction applied to a variable that contains an object (variables ending with "@") add a new object to the object pointed to by the variable.
This example create a bob and adds the "Joystick Movement" object to it.

parameters.name: variable

descriptions.text: Define a list of values to be read at runtime, either string or numbers, separated by commas. Data can be spread on several lines

content.text: A DATA statement lets you include whole lists of useful information in your programs. Each item in the list must
be separated by a comma, like this:
Also each DATA instruction must be the only statement on the current line, because anything that follows it will be
ignored! Prove that with the following line:
Data "I am legal" : Print "But I am not!"
Data can be "read" into one or more variables, and unlike many Basic languages, AOZ allows you to include expressions as part of your data. So the following lines of code are all equally acceptable:
Examine those lines, and note that the A at Label will be input as the contents of variable A, and not the character
A. The expression will be evaluated using the latest value of A.
Data statements may be placed at any position in your program, but any data stored inside an AMOS Professional
procedure will not be accessible from the main program. Each procedure can have its own individual set of data
statements, which are completely independent from the rest of the program.

descriptions.text: Read the next valkue from the Data section of the code, and move the read-pointer to the next value. The type of the value must be identical to the typ eof the variable (number for numbers, strings for strings)

content.text: When READ loads items of information that have been stored in a DATA statement into a list of variables, it uses a
special marker to jump to the first item in the first DATA statement of your listing. As soon as that item of data has
been read, the marker moves on to the next item in the list.
It must be remembered that the variables to be read must be of exactly the same type as the data held at the current
position. If you match up one type of stored data with a different type of variable after a READ command, the
appropriate error message will be given. Here is an example of correct matching:

parameters.name: variable
parameters.text: The variable to read the data into.

descriptions.text: Position the data pointer to the beginning of the data definition or the data immediately following a label inside of the code

content.text: To change the order in which your data is read from the order in which it was originally stored, you can alter the
point where a READ operation expects to find the next DATA statement. The RESTORE command sets the position
of this pointer by referring to a particular label or line number, and both labels and numbers may be calculated as
Each AOZ procedure has its own individual data pointer, so any calls to the command will apply to

RESTORE is one of the AOZ programmer's most useful devices to force the computer to select information, depending on the actions of the user. It can be used for educational and business routines as well as

parameters.name: label
parameters.text: Indicate the position int he source code to restore to

content.text: The ARRAY function returns the address in memory of the first item in the specified list$ array. This string can
contain any data at all, but if the array is to be accessed from an Interface program, each element in the array must
be of exactly the same length.

descriptions.text: Instructions and functions to handle and detect zones
Reserve memory to store graphical detection zones in the current screen

content.text: The RESERVE ZONE instruction must be used to allocate enough memory for the exact number of zones required,
before a SET ZONE command is given. There is no limit to the number that can be specified, apart from the amount
To erase all current zone definitions and restore the allocated memory to the main program, simply give the
RESERVE ZONE command without any number parameter.

parameters.name: number
parameters.text: The number of zones to allocate. If ommited all zones will be erased (not deprecated without parameter)

descriptions.text: Erase the definition of a zone, making it non-detectable

content.text: This command is used to nullify a zone created by the SET ZONE instruction. On its own, RESET ZONE
permanently de-activates all zone settings, but if it is qualified by a zone number, only that zone will be erased.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: The index of the zone to reset, if ommited all zones will be reset

descriptions.text: Return a magical string to use in the Print instruction when printing text, allowing you to define a zone around the text included as a parameter

content.text: The AOZ Studio programmer is allowed to create powerful dialogue boxes and on- screen control panels
without the need to employ complex programming. The ZONES function surrounds a section of text with its own
screen zone, so that the presence of the mouse pointer can be detected using the ZONE function. Simply supply the
two parameters in brackets, which are the string of text for one of your control "buttons", followed by the number of
the screen zone to be defined.
The maximum number of zones will be limited by the value specified in a previous RESERVE ZONE command.
The format for the control string is as follows (please notice that the string is different than the one used in AMOS):

parameters.name: text$
parameters.text: The text to print, the zone will de defined from the top-left corner of the first character to the bottom-right corner of the last character. Warning: impredictible result if the text does not fit in one single line

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: The index of the zone to set

descriptions.text: Define a new zone in the current screen

content.text: After memory has been allocated with the RESERVE ZONE command, SET ZONE is used to define a rectangular
area of the screen which can be tested by the various ZONE functions. The command is followed by the number of
the new zone, followed by its coordinates from top left to bottom right-hand corner.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: The index of the zone to set

parameters.name: x1
parameters.text: The horizontal coordinate of the top-left corner of the zone rectangle

parameters.name: y1
parameters.text: The vertical coordinate of the top-left corner of the zone rectangle

parameters.name: x2
parameters.text: The horizontal coordinate of the bottom-right corner of the zone rectangle

parameters.name: y2
parameters.text: The vertical coordinate of the bottom-right corner of the zone rectangle

descriptions.text: Check if a given coordinate lays inside of a pre-defined zone

content.text: The ZONE function is used to give the number of the screen zone at the specified screen coordinates x,y. These
coordinates are normally relative to the current screen, but an optional screen number can be included before the
After the ZONE function has been called, the number of the first zone at these coordinates will be returned, or False will be given if no zone is detected.
This function can be used with the X BOB and Y BOB functions to detect whether or not a Bob has entered a specific screen zone, as follows:

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: The index of the zone to test

parameters.name: x
parameters.text: Horizontal coordinate to test

parameters.name: y
parameters.text: Vertical coordinate to test

return.text: True if the given coordinate lay inside of the zone, False if not

descriptions.text: Return the index of a predefined zone (with "Set Zone") under the mouse

return.text: -1 if the coordinate lay outside of all the zones, or the index of the zone if they lay inside of one

descriptions.text: Enable a zone in the current screen

content.text: This instruction restores the detection of a specific zone after it has been disabled.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: The index of the zone to enable

descriptions.text: Disable a zone in the current screen

content.text: This instruction allow you to turn off a specific zone: after using it, the zone will not be detected anymore.

parameters.text: The index of the zone to disabled

descriptions.text: Insert scenery for your games, with these commands that allow you to create and manage maps and tiles.
Load a map file. The file must be one of these formats : aozmap, tmx or Tiled json

content.text: This instruction should eb the first one to use if you want to display maps. It loads all the data relative to all the layers of the map, but only the data.
After this instruction, you may want to load the tileset or not.
If you do, everything will be automatic and the next step should be to open a view on the map.
If you do not, then you can create the tileset yourself with the Create Tilset instruction.
The best way to put the files containing the whole map is in the "resources/filesystem/application" folder, this folder being available as a normal disc-drive within your running application.
Once loaded, the map will be refered to from the name of the file without extension.

parameters.name: path$
parameters.text: path to the map to load

descriptions.text: Load all the tiles from a map file, and create the associated images in the image bank to use as tiles.

content.text: This instruction doers all the hard work of loading all the tiles necessary to display your maps, by extracting the graphics from the map tileset image and adding the cut images to the image bank.

The "firstimage" parameter indicates the position of the first image in the image bank. If your image bank already contains images at the position where the imp;orter creates them, they will be replaced by the new images.

It is perfectly possible to load several tileset, they are independant entities, allowing you to completely chaneg the aspect of your game by changing the tileset with one instruction (just make sure that they do not overlap in the image bank).
It only works with tilesets exported by Tiled in eother TSX format or JSON export format. If you use the aozmap format, you will have to create your tileset by hand.

In order to work, you must not forget to add to the same directory where the tileset file is located, the source image from which to extract the graphics. The name of the image should be identical to the name of the titleset file (but for the extension of course).
As for the "Load Map" instruction, the tileset will be refered later by the name of the file without extension.
The next example is extracted from the ZeldaoZ tutorial.
// Load the tilset after image number 1000

parameters.name: path$
parameters.text: Filename to load.

parameters.name: firstImage
parameters.text: Number of the first image to create in the image bank

descriptions.text: Create an empty tileset, each tile being associated to it's number plus the first image in the image bank

content.text: This instruction creates an empty tileset, that is a tileset with all the information by the images themselves. It is up to you to create the images in the image bank, as in this example:
// Load the image containg the tiles and grab them into the image bank after location 1000
Get Image NUMIMAGE, X * 24, Y * 32 To ( X + 1 ) * 24, ( Y + 1 ) * 32
// We can now open our view on layer 0 of the map

parameters.name: name$
parameters.text: Name of the tileset to create

parameters.name: width
parameters.text: Width of the tileset to create

parameters.name: height
parameters.text: Height of the tileset to create

parameters.name: firstImage
parameters.text: Index of the first image to use in the image bank

parameters.name: numberOfImages
parameters.text: Number of images in the tileset

descriptions.text: Link a map to a view

content.text: For complex games, you may need to change the map affected to each view. This function allows you to recover which tileset is used in which view...
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 720		// Set the map display
// Replace the tileset with the other one, changing all graphics on screen
Set View Map "MapView", "mysecondmap"		// Change the map

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

parameters.name: mapName$
parameters.text: Name of the map to associate

content.text: Map files create by Tiled contain several "layers" of tiles. It is a good idea to separate the layer in a game in different sections, like the ground, the obstacles or the ennemies.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 720		// Set the map display

content.text: The value returned is the number of horizontal tiles shown by the view, and is calculated from the width of the display divided by the width of each tiles
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 720		// Set the map display
Print View Width( "MapView" )				// Will print "20" with 64x64 tiles.

Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
Print View Height( "MapView" )				// Will print "11" with 64x64 tiles.

descriptions.text: Reset the maps set and clean all the maps data

content.text: This instructions resets the AOZ Map system to the initial state, as it was when the program was loaded.
Please note that it does NOT detete any image from the image bank, if you want a total reset that includes also the images, you should use the "Del Image" instruction.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

descriptions.text: Store the actual state of a map view

content.text: This instruction associated with the "Pop View" instruction allow you to change anything in your view, the value of tiles and even the map itself safely, knowing that everything can be recovered in its initial state later...
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
Replace Tiles "MapView", 1000, 1001			// Replace all "1000" tiles with 1001

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: ID of the map view

descriptions.text: Restore the state of a map view stored by "View Push" command

content.text: This instruction associated with the "View Pop" instruction allow you to change anything in your view, the value of tiles and even the map itself safely, knowing that everything can be recovered in its initial state later...
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
Replace Tiles "MapView", 1000, 1001			// Replace all "1000" tiles with 1001

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

descriptions.text: Open a view to display a map on the current screen

content.text: This instruction allow you to display the content of a map files. The last parameter defines the number of the layer in the map file...
After it has been used, you need to define the visible area of the view with the "Display View" instruction. Then you are ready to display it with a simple call to "Redraw View".
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

parameters.text: Name of the map

descriptions.text: Close a map Open Viewed with the "Open View" commands.

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

descriptions.text: Return the number of layers in the view's map

content.text: Tiled maps can contain several layer... Each layer is an independant map with it's own tiles.
We suggest to split your maps into several layers. Example:

As you can open as many views as you want on each layer, it is perfectly possible and easy to make paralax scrolling between the planes and achieve greate effect in verical scrolling games such as Cybenet..
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

descriptions.text: Scrolls the map into the view

content.text: Once the maps have been loaded, once the view has been opened and display, this instruction is the key to your game, as it enables the exploration of the map in the view.
As a default, the origin of the map displayed in the view is at 0, 0, the top-left corner of the map will be display at the position of the top-left pixel in the Display View.
You can achieve scrollings by setting the offsets to the view, as you would do for screens with the "Screen Offset" instruction.

You can perfectly set the offset out of the map: in such area nothing will be drawn and the previous graphics will be left in place: if you want a clean display, the extra "Ink" parameter of the "Redraw View" instruction.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
// Slow scrolling on the whole map
Redraw View "MapView", 0				// Make sure the display is clean

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: name of the view

parameters.name: X
parameters.text: Position X in pixel of the scrolling of the view

parameters.name: Y
parameters.text: Position Y in pixel of the scrolling of the view

descriptions.text: Set the position and the size of the view on the current screen

content.text: This instruction should normally be used after you have open a view, but you can also use it anywhere in yoru application.
It defines the rectangle in which to display the map. Width and Height do *not* need to be multiples of the width or height of the tiles...
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 255, 25, 999, 500	// Any size is possible

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

parameters.name: X
parameters.text: Position X in pixel of the view on the current Screen

parameters.name: Y
parameters.text: Position Y in pixel of the view on the current Screen

parameters.name: width
parameters.text: Width of the view in pixel

parameters.name: height
parameters.text: Height of the view in pixel

content.text: This function allows you to retreive the current horizontal offset of the view..
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
Offset View "MapView", View Offset X( "MapView" ) + 1, View Offset Y( "MapView" ) + 1
Redraw View "MapView", 0				// Clear the view rectangle first and then displays the map

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: ID of the map view

return.text: Position in pixel.

content.text: This function allows you to retreive the current vertical offset of the view..
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
Offset View "MapView", View Offset X( "MapView" ) + 1, View Offset Y( "MapView" ) + 1
Cls 0, 0, 0 To 1280, 704				// Make sure the display is clean

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

return.text: Vertical offset in pixels

descriptions.text: Redraw the map view on the screen

content.text: This instruction might be the most fundamental of all the map instruction: it displays the content of the map.
It will only work after all the paremeters have been defined: the map is loaded, the view opened and it's display area set...
You can call it safely without checking first for any change in position or offset: it will not take any processor time or do any change if nothing has changed since the last time it was called.

If you want to *force* this instruction display even if nothing has change, you can simulate a change by doing a non-visible change in the view, like setting the value of a tile to it's value, thus seting the "Redraw" flag to true.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: backColor
parameters.text: Color to use for the background (transparent if not indicated)

descriptions.text: Set the width and height of the tiles in pixel for a specific view, does not affect the original tiles

content.text: This simple instruction enables you to zoom in or out the map inside of the view.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the view

parameters.name: width
parameters.text: Width of the tiles in pixel

parameters.name: height
parameters.text: Height of the tiles in pixel

descriptions.text: Return the number of a specific tile in a map view

content.text: This instructionm scans the tiles currently displayed by the view looking for a specific tile.
If no tile of this value is found, then it returns 0.
If one or more tiles is found, then the value returned is the number of such tile. Please note that it counts a tile as soon as it appears in the view, even a portion of the tile will be counted.
Use this function in your game to detect for example the arrival of ennemies from an "ennemy" layer, detect bonuses etc.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: tileValue
parameters.text: Value of the tile to look for

parameters.name: wholeMap
parameters.text: If set to True, the search will occur on the whole map. If not (default), the search will be conducted only on the visible part of the map.

return.text: Number of specific tiles

descriptions.text: Return the index of the first tile on the map view with this value

content.text: This function and the associated "Tile Next" instruction allow you to scan all the tiles of the same value, either in the visible area or the whole map.
Do not confuse the *index* of a tile in a view and it's value. The index is just the position from the start of the tile in the map array.
This example asks for all the tiles with value "1345" and displays their coordinate in the map.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
TILEINDEX = Tile First( "MapView", 1345, True ) 	// Scans the whole map
Print Tile X( TILEINDEX ), Tile Y( TileIndex )

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: tileValue
parameters.text: Value of the searched tile

parameters.name: wholeMap
parameters.text: If set to True, the search will occur on the whole map. If not (default), the search will be conducted only on the visible part of the map.

return.text: The index of the tile in the view, a number that you can use later in your game to change the tile, -1 if no tile is found.

descriptions.text: Return the next number of tile on the map view after a call to the "Tile First" command.

content.text: This function and the associated "Tile Next" instruction allow you to scan all the tiles of the same value, either in the visible area or the whole map.
This example asks for all the tiles with value "1345" and displays their coordinate in the map.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
TILEINDEX = Tile First( "MapView", 1345, True ) 	// Scans the whole map
Print Tile X( TILEINDEX ), Tile Y( TileIndex )

return.text: The next index of tile found. if -1 is returned then no tile found.

descriptions.text: Return the horizontal position in pixel of a tile in the map view.

content.text: The coordinate returned is the actual coordinate of the top-left corner of the tile on display. It takes into account all the parameters of the view (position and size) as well as the width of the tiles in the tileset.
It means that you can safely use it to over-impose a bob or a sprite as in this example.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
// If the is an ennemy tile in the display, use a bob to display the ennemy...
// The bob will automatically follow the scrolling.
Bob "myennemy", Tile X( "MapView", ENNEMYINDEX ), Tile Y( "MapView", ENNEMYINDEX )

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: tileIndex
parameters.text: Index of tile in the amp

return.text: The horizontal position in pixel.

descriptions.text: Return the vertical position in pixel of a tile in the map view.

content.text: The coordinate returned is the actual coordinate of the top-left corner of the tile on display. It takes into account all the parameters of the view (position and size) as well as the height of the tiles in the tileset.
It means that you can safely use it to over-impose a bob or a sprite as in this example.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
// If the is an ennemy tile in the display, use a bob to display the ennemy...
// The bob will automatically follow the scrolling.
Bob "myennemy", Tile X( "MapView", ENNEMYINDEX ), Tile Y( "MapView", ENNEMYINDEX )

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: ID of the map view

parameters.name: tileIndex
parameters.text: Index of tile in the map

return.text: The vertical position in pixel.

descriptions.text: Return the index of tile at the position x and y on a map view

content.text: This very handy function detects the value of the tile at a specific position on screen. You can use it for example when the user click on the map, as in this example.
// Display the index of the tile under the mouse
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
I = Tile Test( "MapView", X Mouse, Y Mouse )
Print "Tile "; I; " is under the mouse"

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: name of the view

parameters.name: x
parameters.text: Position X in pixel to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.text: Position Y in pixel to test.

return.text: Index of tile found or -1 if the tile is not found.

descriptions.text: Set the image of a specific tile of a Map View

content.text: When you load a map and open a view, there is a direct reference between the *value* of the tile and the image taken out of the image bank and displayed.
This instruction allows you to change the image assigned to the tiles of a specific value. AOZ keeps an internal reference table to perform the indirection.
It does not affect the original map, just the view.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
// Change the image of the tile the user is clicking on
I = Tile Test( "MapView", X Mouse, Y Mouse )
If I >= 0 Then Set Tile Image "MapView", I, 1111

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: tileIndex
parameters.text: Index of tile.

parameters.name: imageIndex
parameters.text: Index of the image

descriptions.text: Return the index of the image used to display a tile in the view

content.text: When you load a map and open a view, there is a direct reference between the *value* of the tile and the image taken out of the image bank and displayed.
If you use this function immediately after loading the map and opening the view, it will return the value of the tile as it will also be the index of the image used.
The return value will change after a Set Tile Image instruction.
This example display the index of the image of the tile under the mouse.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
I = Tile Test( "MapView", X Mouse, Y Mouse )

parameters.name: viewName$
parameters.text: Name of the map view

parameters.name: tileIndex
parameters.text: Index of the tile

return.text: The index of the image

descriptions.text: Change the value of a specifc tile in a view

content.text: You can modify the aspect of your map in real time with this function.
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
// Change the image of the tile the user is clicking on
I = Tile Test( "MapView", X Mouse, Y Mouse )
If I >= 0 Then Set Tile Value "MapView", I, 10

This example display the value of the tile under the mouse.

Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display

descriptions.text: Change the internal string of a specifc tile in a view

content.text: Sometimes you need to keep data associated with a specific tile, like for example a door, if it is open or closed.
AOZ allows you to store data in the form of a string of character in each tile of the map and recover it later...
Open View "MapView", "mymap", "tileset", 0	// Open view on layer 0 of map
Display View "MapView", 0, 0, 1280, 704		// Set the map display
I = Tile Test( "MapView", X Mouse, Y Mouse )
If Mouse Click Then Set Tile String "MapView", I, "hello AOZ!"

descriptions.text: Assign an AOZ procedure to touch-screen events.

descriptions.text: Instructions and functions to access the system resources. Will be implemented in the future if possible in Javascript.
Open a device. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: The DEV OPEN command opens a communication port and prepares the device for use by AOZ
programs. If this device is not already installed, it will be loaded from the "DEVS" folder of your current start-up
disc automatically. Floppy disc users may be requested to swap discs at this point.
The selected device will now remain active during the course of the program, and will only be closed if a DEV
CLOSE command is called, or a RUN command is used to clear the variable area, or a CLEAR operation is
The specified channel number should be from zero to 4, the "name.device" parameter enters the name of the device
to be initialised in normal AmigaDOS format, and IOlength specified the length of the IO structure to be created for
the device. If in doubt, use a value of 256, which should be sufficient for most devices. The final flags parameter
sets the status of the device flags if applicable. Please refer to your system documentation for details.
DEV OPEN performs the following operations:
- Firstly, a communication port is created and initialised.
- Next, an IO Ext structure is opened, ready for communication.
- Lastly, the OPEN DEVICE function is executed with the new structure.

descriptions.text: Close a device. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: Use this command to close one or more open devices.
Memory used by the IO structure will be returned back to AOZ and the message port is released for
subsequent use. If the channel number is omitted, all active devices are closed simultaneously, otherwise the single
specified device is closed down. Note that if a specified channel is not already open, no error will be reported.

descriptions.text: Get base address of an IO structure. May be implemented in AOZ later

content.text: This function returns the base address of the IO structure assigned to the current device. The structure can now be
manipulated directly, using the STRUC commands, as required.

return.text: 0 in this version

descriptions.text: Call a command using DoI0. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: The DEV DO instruction executes a DoIO operation via the specified channel. Obviously the correct internal
structure parameters must be set using a STRUC command, before this operation is called. The specified channel
number refers to a previously opened device channel. The command number holds the number of the IO command
you wish to Do. This command may be entered directly by name, using the EQU function explained earlier. You are
warned to take great care when using this instruction!"

descriptions.text: Call a command using SendIO. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: This calls the SendIO command from Exec, and runs your operation using the Amiga's multi- tasking system. The
new process will run invisibly in the background, and your AOZ program will continue from the next

descriptions.text: Abort an IO operation. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: This instruction executes an AbortIO and a WaitIO command, clearing all pending action from the specified device
channel. It can be used to exit directly from a multi-tasking operation, without waiting for it to complete.

descriptions.text: Check status of a device with a CheckIO. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: Use this function to perform a CheckIO on the specified channel. The resulting value is passed back to AOZ Studio.

return.text: 0 in this version

descriptions.text: Get the first device from the current device list. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: This function is similar to DIR FIRST$. A string is returned identifying the first device that satisfies a chosen search
path in the current device list.
DEV FIRST$("**") will list everything, DEV FIRST$("D/**") will only list disks, and DEV FIRST$(A/**") is used
if you only want to list assigns.

return.text: "" in this version

descriptions.text: Get the next device from the current device list. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: This function is similar to DIR FIRST$. A string is returned identifying the first device that satisfies a chosen search
path in the current device list.
DEV FIRST$("**") will list everything, DEV FIRST$("D/**") will only list disks, and DEV FIRST$(A/**") is used
if you only want to list assigns.

return.text: "" in this version

descriptions.text: Open a library. May be implemented in AOZ (for example for Windows DLLs), has no effect in current version

content.text: The LIB OPEN command calls the OPEN LIBRARY function from EXEC. If the library is external, it will be
loaded into memory from the "Libs: folder of your current start-up disc. If a problem is encountered, you will be
helped by the relevant error message from AOZ, and the error can easily be intercepted using a
After the library has been initialised successfully, it remains open until the program is run again from the Editor, or
your variables are re-set using a CLEAR command, or a LIB CLOSE command is called.
Three parameters are needed for a LIB OPEN instruction. The number of a new AOZ channel, to be
used to refer to this library throughout the AOZ program. Then the name of the library that is to be
opened, given in standard Commodore format. Lastly, the minimum version number of the library that is to be
installed in memory should be specified. If you are unsure of this parameter, use a value of zero.

descriptions.text: Close a library. May be implemented in AOZ (for example for Windows DLLs), has no effect in current version

content.text: Used on its own, the LIB CLOSE command closes all open libraries in a single operation. If an optional Channel
number is included, an individual library may be closed. Please note that if a selected library does not exist, no error

descriptions.text: Call a function from the libraryEnd Function. May be implemented in AOZ (for example for Windows DLLs), has no effect in current version

content.text: This important function acts as the gateway to all the functions in the selected library. It calls the required function
and returns the result to your AOZ program.
The function offset parameter holds the offset value to the library function that you wish to execute, and if it is
entered directly this value must be exact. Any mistakes will crash the computer. Alternatively, you are recommended
to use a safer method via the LVO function to call the command by name, which is explained below.
Before calling this function, the appropriate parameter values need to be loaded into the Address and Data registers,
using the AREG and DREG commands. The precise format of these parameters depends on the function in question,
and should be checked from the appropriate reference manual.
After the function has been successfully executed, any return values will be available for immediate use from the
AREG and DREG variables. Note that AREG only allows the registers from A0 to A3 to be accessed. (Registers
A4, A5 and A6 are not used by the libraries at all.)"

descriptions.text: Get the base address of the library. May be implemented in AOZ, has no effect in current version

content.text: LIB BASE is used to return the base address of the selected library. This can be used in conjunction with the
STRUC function to manipulate the internal data structures directly. Obviously, the normal PEEK and POKE
functions can be used for this purpose as well.

return.text: 0 in this version

descriptions.text: Execute a system command. This instruction will be implemented in executable and node.js transpiled applications

content.text: The EXEC instruction executes the specified CLI command, via the named output. Output refers to the name of an
AmigaDos device, and is held in inverted commas. If these are empty , NIL: will be used, otherwise the name of
the output device must end with a colon.
CUR: specifies that the current CLI window is to be used. If this window does not exist, because AMOS
Professional was booted from the Workbench, then the EXEC command cannot operate. If "CON: is used, then a
CLI window is opened under the Workbench screen, if possible. Any other Amiga device can be specified, as long
as it is interactive, and it will be opened before the CLI command is sent, and closed again after the command has
been sent, unless it is the current CLI window.
For example, to execute an external program copied into the C: directory of AOZ Studio, and wait for its
Amos To Back : Rem Reveal the Workbench
Rem Now launch the program in a small CLI window
Amos To Front : Rem Return to AMOS Pro after the program

Parallel Interface, or the RS232 Port, or the printer chosen in your preferences settings. All standard sequential file
commands can be performed as usual, except for commands that are specific to disc operations, such as LOF and
This example would print out ten lines via the device connected to the Amiga's RS232 port:

descriptions.text: You can play music and sound effects inside your AOZ programs, using the old MOD and XM file formats.
The main advantage of this type of file is its small size. You can store music on several voices as well as sound effects. The AOZ instructions allow you to load and play your files.
AOZ uses the BassoonBassoonTracker Javascript library from Steffest, available under the MIT license.
Github: https://github.com/steffest/BassoonBassoonTracker
Enable the loop playing

content.text: Use these commands to make BassoonTracker modules loop over and over again, or to stop a particular loop after it has

descriptions.text: Disable the loop playing

content.text: Use these commands to make BassoonTracker modules loop over and over again, or to stop a particular loop after it has

descriptions.text: Load a module music file into a bank

content.text: Use this command to load a specified BassoonTracker module into the memory bank number of your choice. Any existing
data in this bank will be erased before the module is loaded, and the new bank will be called "BassoonTracker".

parameters.name: path$
parameters.text: The filename of the module to load

parameters.name: bank
parameters.text: The bank to store the module loaded

exceptions.text: The format of the file is not supported. Only MOD and XM files are supported.
Bank number must be greater than 6.
The module music file not found.

descriptions.text: Play a music module loaded with Track Load instruction or Load Asset instruction

content.text: To start your BassoonTracker module playing, give this command followed by the appropriate bank number. If the bank
number is omitted, bank number 6 will be used as a default. Most electronic composers use sets of patterns to make
up a tune, and these can be repeated in any suitable order. A BassoonTracker sequence can be started from any one of these
patterns, providing that you know which pattern number refers to which particular part of the sequence. An optional
pattern number can be added after the bank number parameter. Here are some example settings:
Track Play : Rem Use default BassoonTracker bank
Track Play ,5 : Rem Play pattern 5 from default BassoonTracker bank
Track Play 9,5: Rem Play pattern 5 from bank 9

parameters.name: bank
parameters.text: The bank number containing the loaded module

parameters.name: pattern
parameters.text: The starting pattern (0 by default)

descriptions.text: Load a module music file into a bank

content.text: The MED LOAD instruction loads the specified module in memory, and re-locates it to the specified reserved bank
in Chip memory. This bank is not a data bank, and will not be saved along with your program, so Med modules
must be loaded anew each time that the program is run.
This command will open the "Medplayer.library" file, and you may be asked to insert your System disc into the
drive if this file is not available on the current disc.
As with BassoonTracker modules, AOZ Studio sound samples can be played while Med modules are active. When a
sound effect is triggered, any Med music will be stopped on all four voices, and will start again as soon as the

parameters.name: path$
parameters.text: The filename of the module to load

parameters.name: bank
parameters.text: The bank to store the module loaded

exceptions.text: The format of the file is not supported. Only MOD and XM files are supported.
Bank number must be greater than 6.
The module music file not found.

descriptions.text: Instructions and functions to translate texts
Instructions and functions to use WebSockets
Open a Web Socket channel, enabling you to send and receive messages and files

content.text: The WebSocket extension allows you to connect to several servers at the same time. To do so, it works with channels, each channel corresponding to a connection. The first parameter of each WebSocket instruction is therefore the index of the channel.

AOZ tries to connect immediately after this instruction but does not wait for the connection to be established. In order to know if the destination WebSocket server has been effectively reached, you must use the "WebSocket Is Connected" function.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

parameters.name: url$
parameters.text: URL of the server

parameters.name: protocol$
parameters.text: List of sub-protocols, as described in the Javascript WebSocket object documentation.

descriptions.text: Destroys a WebSocket channel and all data associated

content.text: Closes any connection and destroys the channel. Any pending message will be lost, the connection is cut without any warning to the other side.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

descriptions.text: Send a message through a WebSocket channel

content.text: The WebSocket channel must be of course connnected for this instruction to work. The message is send without any verification of reception, it might get lost or some parts of it deleted in case of a bad connection.
It is suggested for important data, to ask for a confirmation feed-back from the server side.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

parameters.name: message$
parameters.text: Message to send, no check on length is performed.

descriptions.text: Returns TRUE if a new message is available, FALSE if not

content.text: This function is designed to be used in the main loop of your application.
If it returns true, it means that one or more messages are available, and that you should ask for them with the "WebSocket Message$" function.
This example connects to a server, sends a message and disconnects as soon as it receives a response from the server...

parameters.name: idnex
parameters.text: Index of the channel

return.text: TRUE or FALSE if a new message is available

descriptions.text: Returns a newly arrived string message

content.text: If a message is available in the pile of received messages, this function unpiles the last one and returns it.

As several messages can be received in a short period of time, or if your application leaves the main loop for a moment, you should unpile all the messages and ensure that the message pile stays empty.
(use the "WebSocket Is Message()" function to get this information)
The next examples opens a connection, send a message, then wait and print incoming messages. If the incoming messages is equl to quit, then it quits!

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

return.text: The message

descriptions.text: Returns TRUE if a an error has occurred, FALSE if OK

content.text: This function reports any error with the connection. You can get the description of the error (directly from your browser's response, in its language and format) with the "WebSocket Error$" function.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

return.text: TRUE or FALSE if an error has occured.

descriptions.text: Returns TRUE if the WebSocket has succesfully connected to the server

content.text: This function allows you to wait for the socket to be connected.

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

return.text: TRUE or FALSE if the WebSocket is connected or not.

descriptions.text: Returns the last error message

content.text: You should always in your main program loop check for errors if you have connections running in the back.
To do so, first use the "WebSocket Is Error()" function, that returns true if an error occured, and then ask for the description of the error with this function.
If you are stuck with a indesciferable message, just Google it; you will see tyhat you were not the only one!

parameters.name: index
parameters.text: Index of the channel

return.text: The message
